title: Using variables to build text output: concatenation, f-strings, and join()
content:
Variables often hold **pieces of text** that you combine into messages. Here are common beginner-friendly patterns.

---
## 1) Concatenation with +

```python
first = "Good"
second = "morning"
msg = first + " " + second + "!"
print(msg)  # Good morning!
```

Concatenation requires both sides to be strings:

```python
score = 42
# print("Score: " + score)  # TypeError
print("Score: " + str(score))
```

---
## 2) f-strings (usually easiest to read)

```python
name = "Mika"
score = 42
print(f"{name} scored {score} points")
```

You can format numbers too:

```python
pi = 3.1415926
print(f"piâ‰ˆ{pi:.2f}")
```

---
## 3) str.format()

```python
name = "Mika"
score = 42
print("{} scored {} points".format(name, score))
```

---
## 4) join() for many strings
When joining many parts, build a list and join.

```python
parts = ["A", "B", "C"]
print("-".join(parts))  # A-B-C
```

---
## 5) A small, realistic example

```python
user = "ana"
items = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
count = len(items)

line1 = f"User: {user}"
line2 = "Items: " + ", ".join(items)
line3 = f"Count: {count}"

print(line1)
print(line2)
print(line3)
```
